Evaluate if the sequence meets the strictly increasing condition with the proposed formula or properties.
Verify the existence and uniqueness of such a sequence, potentially by mathematical induction or contradiction.
Identify the smallest possible value of a_1 within the sequences that satisfy all conditions laid out.

Define what it means for a sequence \((a_1, a_2, ...)\) to be strictly increasing.
Set up the initial condition by examining the consequence of the given property \(a_{mn} = a_m + a_n\) on the sequence.
Analyze the implication of \(a_{mn} = a_m + a_n\) specifically for small values of m and n, such as \(a_{1 \cdot n} = a_1 + a_n\) and \(a_{m \cdot 1} = a_m + a_1\).
Determine the general form of \(a_n\) assuming \(a_1\) is a known non-negative number.
Investigate if there is a lower limit or smallest possible value for \(a_1\) such that all conditions hold across all \(m\), \(n\) and maintaining the strictly increasing condition.
Check if a real sequence exists when \(a_1\) is at its calculated minimum and validate this against the original property and the strict increase condition.
Determine if the sequence can be extended indefinitely while satisfying all given conditions.
